title: Exposing hackerone users personally identifiable information by abusing sandbox with swag reward enabled

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi HackerOne Team,

**Summary:**

I have found a critical bug but this will require a bit user interaction, __BUT__ please take note that once exploited, a hackerone user's __PII - personally identifiable information__ can be exposed. I have found this bug by using the __sandbox__ with swag reward enabled .

---

Let me explain first on how this work, basically when the program reward a swag to a hacker, all the hacker swag information here: `https://hackerone.com/settings/swags` will be send to the program owner for proper shipping etc. and can be seen on this end point: `https://hackerone.com/<program_handle>/swag`

__Now i have found a way to use that to expose a Co-hackers PII listed below:__

- __Complete Name__
- __Street__
- __City__
- __State/Province__
- __Postal Code__
- __Country__
- __Phone Number__

The question is how ? , please see below steps.

### Steps To Reproduce

  1. Create a sandbox program and enable the swag rewarding `On`
  2. Now add any team member, base on my experience most hackers are interested to collaborate when you add them to the sandbox.
  3. New team member will most likely play with the sandbox like __Creating test report__, closing reports, rewarding etc.
  4. __NOW THIS IS THE BUG__, when the hackers invited to the sandbox, and then they created a test report, the program owner can reward a swag and then expose their __PII__, because the sandbox program owner can see all of the swag information here: `https://hackerone.com/<program_handle>/swag`

---
### LIVE EXPLOITATION
---

I invited a co-hacker to my sandbox, his hackerone username is https://hackerone.com/█████████ , he joined and play with the sandbox, __WITHOUT KNOWING__ that when he submitted a test report, I already exposed his PII because i rewarded his submitted report a swag, please see below information belonging to him.

 __Complete Name:__ `██████████`
__Street:__ `████`
__City:__ `███████`
__State/Province:__ `███`
__Postal Code:__ `████`
__Country:__ `██████████`
__Phone Number:__ `███`

The other information on the screenshot is for Name: [John Doe](https://hackerone.com/demo-hacker) and those information is belonging to the demo-member.

This bug can be used to expose any target of your choice :)

{F301676} 

### Mitigation:

Hackers swag information (PII) should not send to the __Sandbox or Non-approved program owner__ since this is a testing only and live production hacker information should not be able to disclosed!.

## Impact

Information disclosure, exposing hackerone users personally identifiable information.

Let me know if anything else is needed, please ask question if you are having trouble understanding my report, I'd be glad to provide as much as information if needed. 

Regards
Japz

activities.message: btw, after i discover this.. i ask permission to [█████](https://hackerone.com/█████████) if i can use his information for PoC purposes before submitting this to hackerone team and he gave me a go signal (DM) on his twitter.

Hi @japz - thanks for bringing this to our attention. I agree that this is a risk, but it's one that we accept for now. The invitation clearly states that the user needs to use caution while accepting the invitation for a sandboxed program. We may eventually decide to not show the Swag addresses at all in the sandbox, but it's not a priority for the time being. I like the creativity of the issue though, definitely keep them coming! Thanks again and happy hacking!

Hi @jobert 

Please read my comments carefully:

>I agree that this is a risk

Indeed there is a risk because once successfully exploited, the information expose includes PII.

>but it's one that we accept for now. The invitation clearly states that the user needs to use caution while accepting the invitation for a sandboxed program.

Jobert, i don't think the warning message in the email is enough, let's take a look __what's wrong__ in the warning message: `Warning: This team has not yet been verified by HackerOne. Please exercise caution when providing any sensitive information.`

{F301825}

The very important line is *__Please exercise caution when providing any sensitive information__*

__The thing is__, the victim did not provide me the sensitive information , __HackerOne GIVES IT TO ME!__

## So the system flow is:

  1. User/Victim trust hackerone, they give PII in the swag details (includes full address, phone number, etc.)
  2. Information is now on HACKERONE, and hackerone handling those information with care :)
  3. Now attacker/malicious users used the logical bug and exploit it using the technique that i describe above.
  4. HackerOne automated swag rewarding system gives the information to the attacker

__NOTE:__ Contradicting to the warning message in email, __THE VICTIM DID NOT PROVIDE THE PII TO THE ATTACKER, HACKERONE WAS THE ONE WHO PROVIDED IT__.

Ask more information if you needed @jobert 

I will be waiting for your response.

Cheers
Japz

Hi @jobert ,

If you think you'll disagree with my point on my comment after your response, I would like to request a disclosure of this submission as it affects some users.

I would like them to be aware of this attack.

Just please redact the PII information on my initial description.

Regards
Japz

@japz I agree with @jobert's assessment that we warn the user (both on invite and on sharing swag address). We could clarify the copy or as @jobert said not show swag to sandbox programs (may do more in the future) but we see this as an acceptable risk at this time.
